title: Anisphia Wynn Palettia and Good Permutations
statementHtml:
Anis and her new assistant Euphie are improving the Witch's Broom! Magicology requires great precision and care — in order to fly, the construction of the broom must have sufficiently few imperfections.

For an arbitrary array aa of length mm, call an index ii (1≤i≤m−21≤i≤m−2) bad if aiai, ai+1ai+1, and ai+2ai+2 are all pairwise coprime. More formally, ii is a bad index if and only if gcd(ai,ai+1)=gcd(ai,ai+2)=gcd(ai+1,ai+2)=1gcd(ai,ai+1)=gcd(ai,ai+2)=gcd(ai+1,ai+2)=1∗∗. Furthermore, call aa good if it has at most 66 bad indices.

You are given an integer nn. Construct a good permutation†† pp of length nn. It can be shown that such a permutation always exists.

Note that you do not have to minimize the number of bad indices.

∗∗gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y) denotes the greatest common divisor of xx and yy

†† A permutation of length nn is an array that contains every integer from 11 to nn exactly once, in any order.
inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104)  — the number of test cases.

The only line of each test case contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤2⋅1053≤n≤2⋅105).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output on a single line nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn, an example of a good permutation of length nn. If there are multiple good permutations, you may output any of them.
noteHtml:
For n=9n=9, we have

iipipipi+1pi+1pi+2pi+2gcd(pi,pi+1)gcd(pi,pi+1)gcd(pi,pi+2)gcd(pi,pi+2)gcd(pi+1,pi+2)gcd(pi+1,pi+2)
11554488111144
22448811441111
33881199111111
44119933111133
55993366333333
66336622331122
77662277221111

The only bad index is 33. Since 1≤61≤6, pp is a good permutation.
